generated_text: The structure of ice II, which is the most stable phase of water at high pressure and low temperature, has been a long-standing puzzle. In this work, we report the synthesis and structure of neon hydrate, which is the first example of a hydrate with ice II structure. The guest atoms are enclathrated in the ice II channels, and the guest–host interactions are weak. The structure of neon hydrate is stable at 480 MPa and 260 K, which is the highest pressure and lowest temperature at which a hydrate has been studied. The results provide insights into the structure of ice II and the mechanism of enclathration. They also provide a new route to study the structure of ice II and the mechanism of enclathration.

We provide a categorical definition of quantum mechanics. The definition is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. It is based on a small number of axioms that are satisfied by the category of Hilbert spaces and operators on them. The axioms are similar to those of group representations, but the objects are not assumed to be groups. The definition is intended to be useful for the reconstruction of quantum mechanics from first principles.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that are the most diverse group of parasitic animals. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first comparative analysis of the genomes and transcriptomes of two distantly related species of myxozoans and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan genome is one of the smallest reported in animals, and that the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic myxozoan was accompanied by extreme reduction in gene content. These results provide insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade host antiviral responses is a common strategy used by pathogens to persist and propagate in their host. In this study, we show that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 is able to block nuclear import of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs) proteins, impairing the induction of antiviral genes. We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and interacts with Nup98-Rae1, a protein complex involved in the nuclear import of ISGs. We show that the interaction with Nup98-Rae1 is required for the antiviral activity of Orf6. Our data unveil a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the antiviral response of the host and may help to design new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s food production will have to increase by 70% by 2050 to feed a projected 9 billion people. This increase will be particularly challenging in the tropics, where the optimum growing temperature is exceeded in many places. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values as the global mean temperature increases. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and to a decrease in mean yields. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the 800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in grasslands. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because species-level identification of plant material is prohibitively time-consuming. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between species, even when species were matched in body size and digestive physiology. Moreover, diet composition differed between grazing and browsing guilds, and between grazers and browsers. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages. Our results also highlight the importance of plant diversity in grasslands, which is often overlooked in studies of large herbivore ecology. Collectively, these findings suggest that the role of large herbivores in grasslands may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This may have important implications for the conservation of grasslands worldwide.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis, and many are financially fragile. Many small businesses plan to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program. We also assess the effects of loans relative to grants.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the plastic debris load on the open ocean surface is much less than expected, on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than the 10 million tons estimated in the last decade. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of plastic debris smaller than 1 mm by a combination of processes that are still to be identified. This study provides a baseline for future studies on the impacts of plastic debris in the ocean.

The origin of the elements is one of the most fundamental questions in science. The study of the origin of the elements in meteorites is one of the most powerful ways to understand the evolution of the universe. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. The grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The grains are the oldest presolar grains that have been found so far.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The global fleet could double again by midcentury, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is the defining characteristic of all life on Earth. In this study, we investigate the factors that limit reproductive output in mammals and the extent to which domestication and allonursing can increase reproductive output. We find that domestication and allonursing increase reproductive output, but the extent to which this occurs depends on the amount of energy available to the mother. The greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This study also highlights the importance of the mother in determining the number and size of offspring. This is the first study to our knowledge that investigates the extent to which domestication and allonursing can increase reproductive output. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This study also highlights the importance of the mother in determining the number and size of offspring. This is the first study to our knowledge that investigates the extent to which domestication and allonursing can increase reproductive output.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II clinical trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to limit the neurotoxicity of α-syn aggregation in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major advance in the treatment of MSA and other α-synucleinopathies. The results also provide a rationale for the use of the caspase-1 inhibitor in other neurodegenerative diseases. This study opens the way for a phase I clinical trial in MSA patients. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It controls the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to detect and respond to specific stimuli. The endothelium is also the first line of defense against infection and injury. The endothelium is composed of thousands of cells that are connected to each other by a network of short-range connections. The network is designed to be both efficient in the transmission of signals and robust in the detection of changes in the environment. The network is also designed to be highly synchronized. These properties are important for the endothelium to control the cardiovascular system and to protect the body from infection.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a major public health crisis, with enormous data needs. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data platform that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These include signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The COVIDcast API also tracks all revisions to historical data, allowing modelers to account for the frequent revisions and backfill that are common for many public health data sources. The data and software are available through the API and accompanying R and Python packages. This platform is intended to empower research and decision-making, and to help fill the data gaps that have been identified during the pandemic.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in potassium channels. The activation gate closes the selectivity filter, and the selectivity filter is essential for the channel’s function. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this Threonine residue is essential for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is essential for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is only beginning to be understood, and the potential for natural products to regulate the composition of the microbiome is an emerging area of research. Here, we report the discovery of a large number of natural products that are produced by anaerobic fungi that inhabit the gastrointestinal tracts of herbivores. These fungi are a previously unappreciated source of natural products that could be harnessed for the benefit of human health.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, yet whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that trait anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. This work presents a digital synthesis approach to design multifunctional mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors. The proposed approach is based on the inverse design of composite structures that are composed of multiple materials with distinct behaviors. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and heteroassembly. The fabricated devices exhibit complex and programmable behaviors, which are physically and accurately realized. The proposed approach can be extended to design multifunctional devices with desired behaviors and can be applied to a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major component of the oxygen transport system in vertebrates. The hemoglobin system is regulated by a complex network of genes and proteins. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid tissues. IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is downregulated in the adult bone marrow. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is a key regulator of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid tissues. The results suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. In this study, we found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through the transcription factor sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1) and its transcriptional target stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1). This resistance to ferroptosis is mediated by sustained activation of mTORC1 and the induction of SREBP1. In contrast, mTORC1 inhibition sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis, and this sensitivity is lost when SREBP1 is ablated. These findings suggest that mTORC1 inhibition is a promising strategy for cancer therapy in the presence of PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. The combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy in the presence of PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. These findings also suggest that ferroptosis may be a useful therapeutic target in the presence of PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2) blockers (LCCBs). We show that LCCBs activate the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stromal-interacting molecule (STIM) Ca2+ sensor proteins and the plasma membrane ORAI Ca2+ channels, which drive vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) remodeling. Our data indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our findings have implications for the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed forest management on 10 million hectares of federal land. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older forest and its associated bird species, but that the policy failed to reverse the decline of older forest and its associated bird species. The NWFP failed to halt the decline of early-seral forests, which are important for many bird species. The NWFP also failed to halt the decline of older forest in two ecoregions, the Coast Range and Cascades, where the decline of older forest is most pronounced. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The predicted best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. This approach can be extended to other antibiotic classes. The results of this study are expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics.

We introduce a deep convolutional neural network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The network architecture is based on a simple idea: use dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connect all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement, train, and apply in practice.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is a classic example of adaptive radiation, where a single ancestral lineage diversified rapidly into a large number of species. The ability of the species flock to adapt to changing environments is thought to be linked to the unique hydroclimate of Lake Malawi, which has been hypothesized to have been highly variable in the past. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of the hydroclimate of Lake Malawi, which shows that the lake underwent large-scale changes in water level, and that the evolution of the species flock coincided with periods of extreme drought. These results provide insight into the role of hydroclimate variability in the evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock. They also highlight the importance of understanding the full range of climate variability in the past to fully appreciate the processes that have shaped the biodiversity of the present.

The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that this practice has important consequences for sleep. The use of electronic devices before bedtime phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and reduces the following night’s sleep. These effects are likely to have important consequences for health, safety, and performance.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) chronostratigraphic boundary is widely recognized as marking the end of the last glaciation and the onset of the current interglacial period. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of bulk sediment and/or magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio is consistent with terrestrial Os, indicating that the YDB is not the result of an extraterrestrial impact. In contrast, the YDB site in Pennsylvania is remarkable in yielding 2- to 5-mm diameter spherules containing minerals such as suessite that form at temperatures in excess of 2000 °C. The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital CTLA-4–deficient mice. We also show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in both the central and the peripheral immune system.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 beetle genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, the major component of plant cell walls. Our results suggest that the first horizontal transfers of genes encoding these enzymes may have triggered adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles, resulting in nearly half of all living beetle species. This study also resolves controversial beetle relationships, dating the origin of beetles to the Carboniferous, and provides evidence that the diversification of beetles was codiversified with the diversification of angiosperms. These results have implications for understanding the evolution of insect herbivory and the origin of plant diversity. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary biologists and cultural ecologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of culture and the emergence of intelligence.

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE4 is the strongest risk factor. We found that APOE is highly associated with the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which are the main cellular components of senescent synapses. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the accumulation of complement component C1q in senescent synapses, which may be the result of defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a mechanistic explanation for the strong association between APOE and AD, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be two-step, in which the bcc phase is the first nucleus. This mechanism reduces the required degree of undercooling of iron nucleation, which solves the inner core nucleation paradox. Our results also provide a new perspective on the structure and anisotropy of the inner core. Our findings are expected to have a significant impact on the understanding of the Earth's interior.

The present study provides evidence that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This blunted reactivity to methylphenidate is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as with increased addiction severity and craving. These findings are consistent with the notion that the reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate is a consequence of the chronic marijuana use, and that this reduced brain reactivity contributes to the addiction and negative emotionality.

We show that the most powerful artificial neural networks in the world are also the most predictive of the human brain’s responses to language. This suggests that the most important feature of these networks is their ability to represent and learn long sequences of symbols. We also show that the predictive power of these networks generalizes across datasets and imaging modalities. Finally, we show that the architecture of these networks is strongly correlated with their predictive power. These results provide computational evidence that the ability of these networks to represent and learn long sequences of symbols is a fundamental feature of the human brain’s language comprehension mechanisms. This work is a major advance in our understanding of the human brain and language processing. It also provides a computational framework for understanding the strengths and weaknesses of different artificial intelligence models. It may also lead to new computational models of the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it is still a black box. We show that the instability of DL is due to the fact that we do not know how to train a stable neural network. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable, and prove that they are sufficient for the existence of stable neural networks. This is a major advance in the theory of neural networks, and will allow us to design stable DL algorithms.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the failure of the pharmaceutical industry to develop a vaccine in time, and the failure of the public to comply with the necessary restrictions. One of the most frequently cited arguments is that people are unable to understand exponential growth. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. We show that the experiment’s design is flawed and that it is not the case that people are unable to understand exponential growth. We also show that the experiment’s conclusion is not supported by the data.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years, and it is still a major public health problem in many parts of the world. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been studied for decades, but the pathogenicity of the uncultured Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes the majority of cases of leprosy, has only recently been investigated. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. Our results suggest that the two pathogens are remarkably conserved despite their ancient separation and that they are still capable of causing similar diseases. This study also provides a phylogeographic survey of the distribution of the two leprosy pathogens and suggests that they are still widespread in Mexico. (Show more)

The entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum systems is a fundamental open problem. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics of the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the natural limit for the study of quantum quenches. We check our result for the paradigmatic case of the entanglement growth during a unitary quench.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people worldwide. The only vaccine currently in clinical development is based on a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain. This study describes the development of this vaccine and its potential for use in mass vaccination programs. The vaccine is highly attenuated, has a large-scale manufacturing potential, and is protective in a relevant hamster model. This study provides a solid foundation for the development of this vaccine and its use in mass vaccination programs. (Show more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that it was spread by rats. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also highlights the importance of human-mediated transmission in the history of plague.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in neuroscience and cognitive science. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is less understood. We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive capacity of animals. We also show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only associated with the evolution of brain size but also with the number of neurons. This study provides a more comprehensive picture of the evolution of brain information-processing capacity and its relationship with animal intelligence.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer is controversial. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study also provides a rationale for the development of TRAP1-specific inhibitors as probes of TRAP1 function in cancer. (Show more)

Actin filaments are the main structural elements of the cytoskeleton, and they are also the main targets of the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins. ADF/cofilin is a key regulator of cell motility and cytokinesis, and it is also involved in the formation of stress fibers and lamellipodia. However, the mechanism by which ADF/cofilin disassembles actin filaments is still unclear. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can sever actin filaments, and we demonstrate that this process is enhanced by a mechanical torque. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the role of ADF/cofilin in the formation of lamellipodia and stress fibers, and they also suggest that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to the disassembly of filament networks in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian people, who settled in the islands of the Pacific, are found in direct contact with the Bantu people, who are the largest ethnic group in Africa. We present a high-resolution genomic analysis of the Malagasy people, which is the first of its kind for an island. Our results show that Madagascar was settled by two different waves of people, one from Southeast Asia and the other from Eastern Africa, and that the settlement happened in a sex-biased and geographically heterogeneous way. These results have important implications for the settlement history of Madagascar and for the diversity of the island. They also highlight the importance of the spatial resolution of the genomic data in the study of human populations. (Show more)

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for the design of social networks, the spread of emotions, and the design of interventions to reduce the spread of negative emotions.

The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that reads messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences and translates the information into a protein. The mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are not the only sequences that are important for translation. The presence of chemical modifications in mRNA sequences can also have profound effects on translation. We show that the presence of a chemical modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in mRNA sequences can modestly alter translation speed and the identity of the amino acid that is added to the growing protein chain. These findings highlight the importance of mRNA sequences beyond the protein-coding region and the impact that chemical modifications can have on translation. This work also provides a structural basis for the effects of Ψ on translation. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more social and economic resources, and less loneliness. These associations are robust to the effects of factors such as socioeconomic status, depressive symptoms, and prosperity. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of body size in mammals is one of the most important and most studied topics in biology. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving mammals toward a relatively small body size in water. This size attractor is consistent with the energetic demands of the aquatic environment, which are more demanding than the terrestrial environment. This study also shows that the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals is not driven by the evolution of new body shapes, but rather by changes in the scaling of the energetic costs and benefits of different body sizes. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of body size in mammals and aquatic animals more generally.

The common cold is one of the most common and most economically costly diseases in the world. The virus that causes the common cold, human rhinovirus, replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at nasal cavity temperature in primary mouse airway epithelial cells due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

The bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in cystic fibrosis patients and other individuals. It is a master of adaptation, and can switch from a free-living state to a biofilm lifestyle, which is a major cause of infections in hospitals. The type IV pili (T4P) are a major surface adhesin of P. aeruginosa, and are essential for the ability of the bacteria to attach to surfaces. Here we show that the bacteria can sense the mechanical activity of the pili, and that this signal is used to regulate the expression of genes involved in surface attachment and virulence. This is a new mechanism of sensing surfaces, and demonstrates that the pili are not only used for motility, but also as a sensor for environmental signals.

The widespread use of pesticides in agriculture has led to a substantial contamination of surface waters. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the occurrence of pesticides in surface waters and the risk of pesticide-induced impairment of aquatic biodiversity. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living animals has raised concerns about the persistence of the virus in the environment and the potential for animal-to-human transmission. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, and the identification of multiple human and deer lineages. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and highlight the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study also provides a unique example of the use of deer as sentinels for the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living animals. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of this problem, the impacts of large dams, and the solutions that are needed. We also propose a new approach to hydropower that can be used to reduce the impacts of large dams and increase the benefits.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques and neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs). The exact mechanisms underlying the development of these pathologies are not fully understood, but it is clear that the immune system plays a significant role. In this study, we demonstrate that neurons are capable of producing a variety of proinflammatory factors, which are released into the extracellular space. These factors are capable of inducing a microglial response, which is a critical component of the AD inflammatory network. Thus, we propose that the neuron is a primary source of the AD immune response, and that this process may be a critical component in the development of AD pathology. This study provides a new perspective on the AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is known from the Hellenistic period in the Southern Levant. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the domestic chicken and its spread across the Mediterranean world.

The folding of large proteins is a major challenge in understanding the principles of protein folding. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that is known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. We find that the intermediates are obligatory steps on the folding pathway and that the folding pathway is more complex than previously thought. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. This list is growing, and it is becoming clear that the folding of large proteins is more complex than previously thought. (Show more)

The presence of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in cells experiencing stress has recently been shown to be critical for the survival of many organisms. However, the cellular mechanisms that regulate the concentration of Np4 in the cell are not well understood. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to remove the cap from transcripts, also removes the Np4 cap. This enzyme is the predominant decapping enzyme in Escherichia coli cells experiencing disulfide stress, and it preferentially removes Np4-capped transcripts over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. The unique manner in which capped substrates of this kind bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which cells regulate the concentration of Np4 in the cell. It also provides a rationale for the use of RppH as a potential target for the development of new antibiotics. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a rationale for the use of citrulline in the treatment of other conditions in which T cell dysfunction is a major factor in the pathogenesis of the disease. This includes cancer, where arginine deprivation is a major mechanism of T cell dysfunction.

The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental quantity that is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly concentrated in the oceans. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and are expected to be useful for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. They also provide a baseline for future studies on the impact of human activities on the biomass of the biosphere.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that this model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts and describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is also a promising material for quantum applications. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by applying tensile strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized by applying compressive strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. Our findings are also relevant for the development of diamond-based devices.

The discovery of a large number of nodule-specific peptides in the model legume Medicago truncatula has led to the hypothesis that these peptides may have a role in plant immunity. However, there is a lack of knowledge regarding their structural architecture, antifungal activity, and modes of action against plant fungal pathogens. Here, we report the structure of one of the most potent antifungal peptides, NCR044, and demonstrate that it is a potent fungicide against multiple plant fungal pathogens. We also show that this peptide has the potential to be developed as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work provides a foundation for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungicide.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely to be a site of molecular exchange. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. We show that the Drosophila sperm proteome undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins are enriched in the sperm proteome after mating, suggesting that the female reproductive tract serves as a reservoir of proteins that support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the platelet surface. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow during bleeding. We show that force application switches VWF to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. Switching occurs near 10 pN, a force that also induces a state of the receptor−ligand complex with slower off-rate. Force greatly increases the effects of VWF mutations, explaining pathophysiology. Conversion of single molecule kon (s−1) to bulk phase kon (s−1M−1) and the kon and koff values extrapolated to zero force for the low-force pathways show remarkably good agreement with bulk-phase measurements. This suggests that the force-dependent pathway is the dominant pathway in the bulk phase. This is the first time that a force-dependent pathway has been observed in a protein system. The results have implications for the mechanism of action of VWF and for the design of biomaterials.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and has only recently begun to receive the attention it deserves. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, and uses it to uncover previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results provide a foundation for future studies of the human microbiome and its impact on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models due to the complexity of this process. Observations of ACI are challenging because of the lack of high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to overcome this conundrum. This instrument can simultaneously measure aerosols and clouds, especially water cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of this instrument by conducting observations over Beijing, China. The observations show that the increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius, consistent with expectations. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the origin and evolution of life. The isotopic record of the oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present a method for reconstructing ancient surface temperatures based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Show more)

Ion channels are the main ion conduits in the cell and are regulated by two gates, one for fast activation/deactivation and the other for slow inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings provide insights into the mechanism of K+ channel regulation. (Show more)

The malaria parasite must overcome a number of physical barriers to successfully invade the red blood cell (RBC) host cell. Here, we show that the malaria parasite’s erythrocyte-binding antigen, EBA175, alters the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is the first demonstration that the parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host cell, which, in turn, may alter the physical forces acting on the parasite and thus facilitate invasion. This work provides a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that the malaria parasite is not simply a mechanical force, but rather a complex system of physical forces that must be overcome to successfully invade the host cell. This work also provides a potential target for the development of new antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, diamond is brittle and easily breaks into pieces. It is also expensive. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be fully closed, without phonon instability. This opens up opportunities to tailor the properties of diamond via strain engineering. We also show that diamond can be used as a mechanical strain sensor. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides mechanistic insights into the impact of ambient humidity on host defense against influenza virus infection and disease outcome. These findings may have implications for the development of influenza vaccine and antiviral therapy. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is based on a model of language that is too simple to capture the brain’s actual processing. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the construction of a sentence is consistent with a model of phrase construction, in which each word is merged into a phrase, and the brain’s activity increases with each successive word. This model is consistent with the brain’s processing of arbitrary-length sequences of words, and it provides a better fit to the data than a model based on sequential probability. Our results suggest that the brain’s processing of language is consistent with a tree-like structure, but that the tree is not a tree of nested phrases. (Show more)

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that regulates development and homeostasis. The pathway is regulated by two key components, the receptor Frizzled (FZD) and the downstream scaffold Axin. Axin is a key component in the pathway, as it is required for the degradation of β-catenin, a key component in the pathway. We show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently, and that this difference is used to regulate the two forms of Axin differently. This is a common feature in vertebrates, and may be used to regulate other redundant genes.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit that includes dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra (SN), as well as LH neurons. We also show that this circuit is necessary for the development of eating after LH stimulation. Finally, we show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work provides a framework for understanding the mechanisms that underlie the development of obesity. (Show more)

Symbiotic nitrogen fixation is a key process in the global nitrogen cycle and is essential for the growth of many plant species. The ability of bacteria to fix nitrogen in the soil is of great interest for the sustainable improvement of agriculture. However, the use of these bacteria as biofertilizers is limited by the lack of a mechanism to control their activity in the soil. Here, we demonstrate the feasibility of controlling the nitrogen-fixing activity of bacteria in the soil by the plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also represents a proof of principle for the use of transkingdom signaling to control the activity of microorganisms in the environment. This approach could be extended to other microorganisms of interest for the sustainable improvement of agriculture. (Show more)

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

We show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear the sounds of its environment by sensing the air particle movements caused by the sound waves. The spider’s hearing is not constrained by its body size, and it can hear the sounds of its environment by outsourcing its hearing to its self-manufactured web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna, which is much more sensitive to the sound-induced air particle movements than the spider’s body itself. The spider’s web is also flexible and can be regenerated after damage. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying acoustic sensing and design. The findings also provide insights into the evolution of hearing in animals. (Show more)

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have devastating effects on global health and the economy. The development of a safe and efficacious vaccine is a critical step toward controlling the pandemic. We report the design and synthesis of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD variant that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits a strong immune response. This variant is amenable to inclusion in a virus-like particle, which further enhances the immune response and reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the engineered RBD variant may be a promising candidate for a subunit vaccine.

The small ALKAL proteins are secreted proteins that are expressed in the developing nervous system. They are implicated in the development of the nervous system in humans and in the regulation of the neuroblastoma ALK/ALKALS in mice and humans. Here, we show that zebrafish ALKALs are able to activate the zebrafish Ltk and human ALK/ALKALS in vitro. We further show that zebrafish ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, pigment cells that are derived from the neural crest. Finally, we show that zebrafish ALKALs are required for zebrafish development. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the activation of ALK/ALKALS by ALKALs and of their involvement in neural crest development.

The emergence of plague, the deadliest pathogen in human history, is a well-known story, but the details of its early evolution are still largely unknown. We present 17 ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from Eurasia dating to the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age (LNBA) period, which is considered a critical time for the emergence of plague. Our results show that plague was not a single lineage but rather a lineage that persisted over millennia without significant diversification. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This work provides a unique perspective on the origins of plague and its relationship to its vector, the flea. (Show more)

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, we find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The management of agricultural systems can affect the amount and distribution of soil organic carbon (SOC) in the soil. We investigated the effects of soil health management practices on SOC storage and the distribution of SOC between particulate and mineral-associated fractions in a long-term field experiment. We found that soil health management practices that reduced soil disturbance, diversified crop rotations, and added manure or legumes to annual cropping systems increased SOC storage and the mineral-associated fraction of SOC. These practices also increased the microbial biomass and C-use efficiency of the soil. In contrast, systems that minimized soil disturbance and added manure or legumes to annual cropping systems increased particulate-associated SOC but did not increase the mineral-associated fraction of SOC. These results highlight the importance of soil health management practices in increasing SOC storage and the mineral-associated fraction of SOC in the long term. This study also highlights the potential of rotational grazing of pastures to increase SOC storage on grasslands. These findings have implications for the management of agricultural systems to mitigate climate change. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 priority viruses for further investigation. The SpillOver platform provides a living, interactive database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinator attraction, but the mechanisms underlying this adaptation are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We demonstrate that this alkaloid is attractive to the gecko pollinators of this plant. We also show that the red color of the nectar of hummingbird-visited plants is likely the result of convergent evolution. This work provides evidence that the red color of nectar is a widespread and convergently evolved trait that is likely to be a key component of the attraction of vertebrate pollinators. This work also highlights the importance of alkaloids in the evolution of plant–animal interactions. (Show more)

We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 6th centuries AD. Our data indicate that the men in this group had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, functional variants indicate that they also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Examination of the panel of functional loci also revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and the evolution of bat coronaviruses. They also provide a rationale for the development

We demonstrate the utility of this approach in the detection of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens. This approach can be used to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings, and can be deployed to better understand the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens.
