The human genome is replicated in a highly coordinated and accurate manner. The lagging strand of the nucleus is replicated by the polymerase δ holoenzyme, which is anchored to the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for eukaryotic DNA replication. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be evolved to have catalytic activity, and in vitro evolution has been used to improve the activity of RNA molecules. Here, we report the results of in vitro evolution of a ribozyme that can synthesize RNA molecules from an RNA template. The evolved ribozyme is able to synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. Furthermore, the evolved ribozyme can replicate RNA molecules, amplify RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold, and synthesize functional proteins. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. We have identified that the pathogenic T cells and inflammatory monocytes with large amount of interleukin 6 secreting may incite the inflammatory storm, which may potentially be curbed through monoclonal antibody that targets the IL-6 pathways. Tocilizumab, which improved the clinical outcome immediately in severe and critical COVID-19 patients, is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic. The fungal pathogen Aspergillus fumigatus has evolved a mechanism to control copper toxicity through the secretion of a family of isocyanide compounds, which bind copper and impact cellular copper content. This study demonstrates that the xan isocyanide family of compounds has antimicrobial properties and that copper-dependent antimicrobial properties of xan BGC isocyanides are conserved in other filamentous fungi. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study also demonstrates the utility of the CAS assay for the detection of metal-binding compounds. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite, a high-temperature polymorph of SiO2, in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a product of high-temperature, low-pressure metamorphism. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals and amorphous silica, and is possibly derived from silicic volcanism in the crater region. The amorphous silica is cogenetic with the other precipitates and is possibly derived from multiple aqueous solutions with variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities.

Frost is a major environmental stressor that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite its ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of frost events are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is strongly correlated with the leaf-out and leaf-freezing strategies of woody species. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of Th17 cells are unknown. We found that Th17 cells were unable to induce colitis in recipients lacking IFN-γ, a finding that was dependent on the expression of the transcription factor T-bet. Th17 cells were also required for the development of colitis, and this requirement was dependent on the expression of the transcription factor Stat4. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease that causes paralysis and death. There is no cure, and the disease is caused by mutations in many genes. We report a method to convert human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced astrocytes. These cells are toxic to motor neurons, a key feature of ALS. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify therapies for ALS. This will also enable the study of the mechanisms of disease and the development of new treatments. This method will also be applicable to other neurodegenerative diseases.

The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the insect microbiota is a key factor in the transmission of infectious diseases. We now show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which is a host-specific antibacterial protein that is expressed by the tick Ixodes scapularis. IAFGP alters the composition of the tick gut microbiota, which in turn influences the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier. These data provide a mechanistic understanding of how a pathogen exploits a host-specific antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides a framework for understanding the role of the microbiota in the transmission of infectious diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important and enigmatic transitions in vertebrate evolution. The discovery of a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis, adds important information about the origin of the modern avian body plan. The presence of a fused scapulocoracoid in adult individuals independently evolved in Jinguofortisidae and Confuciusornithiformes may relate to an accelerated osteogenesis during chondrogenesis and likely formed through the heterochronic process of peramorphosis by which these basal taxa retain the scapulocoracoid of the nonavian theropod ancestors with the addition of flight-related modifications. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. (Show more)

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

The presence of blue-green tissues in vertebrates is a unique feature of the animal kingdom. This phenomenon, known as chlorosis, is thought to be the result of a biochemical mechanism that allows the animal to absorb light in the near-infrared region, which is not available to most animals. We show that this mechanism has evolved multiple times during vertebrate evolution, and that the biochemical basis of chlorosis is the presence of a specific group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a molecule that is abundant in the blood of vertebrates. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis and a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most diverse group of proteins in the animal kingdom. This study also provides a molecular basis for the evolution of green coloration in vertebrates. (Show more)

The ability of cancer cells to maintain their stemness properties is critical for tumor growth and metastasis. We report that hypoxia induces expression of an m6A demethylase, AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn regulates the expression of NANOG, a gene encoding a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is dependent on ALKBH5 and is required for the maintenance of breast cancer stem cell properties. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first printed books were pocket Bibles. The parchment used to make these books was a key innovation, and the source of this parchment has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a method that allows the source of parchment to be identified without the need for invasive sampling. The method is based on the use of a PVC eraser to generate an electrostatic charge on the parchment surface, which is then analyzed by mass spectrometry. The method is noninvasive and allows the identification of the animal species used to make the parchment. We show that the source of the parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was not the use of abortive or newborn animals, but rather the use of hides from maturing animals of several species. This suggests that the production process for this parchment was able to make use of the hides of maturing animals of several species, rather than the use of abortive or newborn animals. (Show more)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for this extinction event is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of extinction and recovery. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.9 and 251.8 Ma, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly variable during the extinction, and the recovery was protracted. These results provide a new benchmark for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms for the extinction. They also provide a new time point for evaluating the recovery of the biosphere after the extinction. The results are important for understanding the causes and consequences of extinction and recovery in the past and for evaluating the likelihood of extinction in the future.

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the external environment. It is essential to maintain intestinal homeostasis to prevent the invasion of pathogens and the immune response against the host. However, the intestinal epithelium is also the first line of defense against the host immune response. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORα deletion leads to excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. We further found that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease. This study also provides a new perspective on the role of RORα in the intestinal epithelium. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with ACE2, the cellular receptor, and an RBD antibody. We find that the D614G mutation, which has become the predominant mutation in SARS-CoV-2, is associated with more open conformations of the RBD, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and fusion. Our data provide insights into the mechanism of action of the D614G mutation and may inform the design of future vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are fundamental to chemistry and are the basis of the periodic table. The chemical hardness and electronegativity are two central properties of atoms, which are the second- and first-order chemical potentials, respectively. We calculate these properties as a function of pressure, and we show that they decrease with pressure, which is consistent with pressure-induced metallization. Furthermore, we show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt are pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them are electron acceptors. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales.

We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been the dominant driver of global fire activity over the past century, with climate change playing a much smaller role. However, climate change may reverse this trend in the future, with implications for the carbon cycle. We show that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective at slowing global warming under lower emission scenarios. Our study highlights that ignitions and fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms that regulate the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its symbiotic bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm that is synchronized with the host’s circadian clock. We also show that the timing of chitin delivery is critical for the persistence of the symbiosis, and that the glycan must be catabolized by the bacterium to maintain a healthy symbiosis. These results suggest that the timing of nutrient delivery may be a general mechanism used by animals to regulate the health of their symbiotic associations. This mechanism may be particularly important in the case of animals that live in complex environments, where the timing of nutrient delivery may be more critical than the quantity of nutrients provided. (Show more)

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We use a generative model to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as discourse atoms. Each atom is a distribution over words, and we can infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives, many of which are not captured by existing structured variables. We also provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. We show that the climate conditions in Asia were favorable for the survival of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague, during the first plague pandemic. This allowed the bacterium to be reintroduced into Europe, via the trade routes, on multiple occasions. Our results suggest that the climate conditions in Asia were favorable for the survival of the bacterium during the first plague pandemic, allowing it to be reintroduced into Europe, via the trade routes, on multiple occasions. This supports the hypothesis that the bacterium was introduced into Europe on multiple occasions, rather than once, as previously thought. Our results also suggest that the bacterium was not introduced into Europe by rodents, as previously thought, but rather by humans. This highlights the importance of trade routes in the spread of the plague.

The asteroid mass mortality (i.e., sea star wasting disease) is one of the most dramatic events in the natural history of the Northeast Pacific Coast. The disease is caused by a virus that has spread rapidly among populations of at least 20 species of asteroids. We show that the virus is the most likely cause of the disease and that it has been present on the North American Pacific Coast for at least 72 y.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common type of leukemia, and the prognosis of AML patients is poor. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) are effective in AML xenograft models. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects, and we show that an antibody targeting IL1RAP can also suppress the proliferation of primary AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, the results suggest that IL1RAP is a promising target for antibody-based treatment of other diseases.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic ancestries, with a common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we show that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive picture of the genetic history of Madagascar, which is a unique case in the Indian Ocean. It also provides a baseline for future studies on the genetic history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean region. This study will also be useful for the study of the genetic history of Africa and Asia.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical, and are often not used in agricultural decision-making. We show that the Crop Progress and Condition survey of the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show that the survey exhibits long-term stability and is valid across the nation. Finally, we demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the Crop Progress and Condition survey is a valuable source of information that can be used to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies. This information can be used to improve agricultural decision-making and reduce the risk of crop failures.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. This ability is thought to be supported by elevated neural activity. However, there is also evidence that short-term synaptic facilitation can contribute to memory. Here we propose a model of memory that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. This model provides a computational account of memory that is based on intrinsic plasticity and does not rely on persistent activity, excitatory feedback, or synaptic plasticity. It is therefore suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. However, despite decades of research, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. This consistent decrease in temperature sensitivity at higher temperatures demonstrates that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is one of the most important events in the evolution of life on Earth. It is also one of the most difficult to study, because it is associated with a loss of information in the genome. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The impact of anthropogenic climate change on the probability of occurrence of droughts in southwestern South Africa is quantified through a large ensemble of climate model simulations. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also highlight the importance of the regional scale in the assessment of the impact of anthropogenic climate change on droughts. This is particularly true for the small-scale droughts that are the focus of this study. The results are relevant to the water resources and food security of the region.

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the “Trinity test,” has been a major event in the history of science. The discovery of the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal, in red trinitite, the first sample of sand that was blasted into the air during the test, is a major event in the history of science and technology. The discovery of this material, which is a new composition of icosahedral quasicrystal, is a major event in the history of science and technology.

The formation of the fifth isocyclic ring in (bacterio)chlorophylls is a key reaction in photosynthesis. The mechanism of this reaction has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This work shows that the O2-dependent cyclase in oxygenic phototrophs is composed of three classes, and that the O2-sensitive cyclase in anoxygenic phototrophs is composed of two classes. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of this reaction. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 is involved in the development of EAE. We also found that ASK1 is involved in the generation of neuroinflammation in both the early and later stages of EAE. We further demonstrated that ASK1 is required for the activation of astrocytes and the recruitment of microglia/macrophages. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a rationale for the use of a phase-specific approach to treat EAE. The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest and warmest on record. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to human activities. We also show that the probability of drought has increased because of the extremely warm conditions that have been more likely when precipitation deficits have occurred. These findings have important implications for the future of California, where the probability of drought is likely to increase further as the climate continues to warm.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder that is caused by multiple genetic factors and environmental factors. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility, which resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and suggests that the activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting is a potential therapeutic target for autism. (Show more)

This work is the first to report cross-national evidence of negativity biases in the news. It also provides the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results are consistent with the hypothesis that the prevalence of negative news content is due in part to the tendency for humans to react more strongly to negative information. They also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) entry (SOCE) pathway is a critical regulator of cellular physiology, but its pathophysiological role in human disease is poorly understood. Here, we identify two mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 that result in a severe hematological disorder, Stormorken syndrome. We show that these mutations lead to constitutive activation of the SOCE pathway, and that the mutations are sufficient to cause the hematological disorder in vitro and in vivo. These data expand our understanding of the pathophysiology of Stormorken syndrome and suggest new therapeutic approaches for patients with this disorder. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process, but the mechanisms underlying this propagation are poorly understood. Here we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to study the spread of protein aggregates in the brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons, demonstrating that they are not cleared by the immune system. We also show that the spread of aggregates is dependent on endocytosis, and that this is required for the loss of vulnerable neurons. Finally, we show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The immune system of bats is highly specialized and is considered to be an immunologically privileged site for microbial community residence. However, the immunosuppressant protein (MTX) identified in this study is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and is a potent immunomodulator that can inhibit the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitate viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into the immunologically privileged site for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to treat viral infections. This study also provides a potential target for the development of antiviral drugs to prevent and treat viral infections in humans and animals. (Show more)

The one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth, and is provided by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). Mammalian SHMT1 is cytosolic, and SHMT2 is mitochondrial. We show that dual knockout of SHMT1/2 blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT1/2, which is effective in cellular assays. However, one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue agent, and paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a cancer cell-line screen. We show that formate is a more effective one-carbon donor in cells that import glycine less efficiently, and thus are uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. This work provides a rationale for the use of formate as a metabolic targeting strategy in cancer. It also provides a rationale for the use of formate as a metabolic targeting strategy in cancer.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations that lead to the formation of intracellular inclusion bodies. These inclusions contain a variety of proteins that do not share obvious characteristics other than coaggregation. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants were aquatic plants that colonized the land. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, opens the possibility that aquatic plants were common at an early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in the field of virology, but the evolutionary history of many viruses is unknown because of the difficulty in obtaining viral sequences from ancient times. Here we present the first ancient viral sequences, which show that the human pathogen B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought, which is important for understanding the evolution of the virus and its impact on humans. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

We show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with climate change. This finding is important because it provides a direct measurement of the rate of climate change, which is a key input to climate models and to the IPCC AR5.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain prevalence has increased with age in the United States since the 1970s, but that pain prevalence has decreased with age in the United States since the 1950s for those with a bachelor’s degree or more. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. Instead, it is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The ability to characterize the structure and dynamics of enzyme active sites is a key goal in enzymology. Here, we demonstrate the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This integrated approach provides insight into the chemical dynamics of the active site, including the location and orientation of crystallographic waters, and the role of the cofactor in the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This detailed picture of the reaction pathway is key to understanding why the natural substrate indole is reactive, while the isostere benzimidazole is not. This work highlights the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography in mechanistic enzymology. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. The high mortality rate of the disease, and the emergence of new cases, stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog that inhibits the viral replication of several RNA viruses, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the further development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses. It may also be considered for a wider range of RNA viruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of the early initiation of antiviral treatment in the context of a viral infection. (Show more)

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms that regulate the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its symbiotic bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. We also show that the timing of glycan delivery is critical for the persistence of the symbiosis, and that the glycan must be catabolized by the symbionts to maintain a healthy symbiosis. These results suggest that the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery may be a general mechanism used by animals to regulate the health of their symbionts. This mechanism may be particularly important in the case of animals that have a short lifespan, such as squid, and rely on a single symbiont species. (Show more)
