DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis are still largely unknown. Here, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcriptional fidelity of RNA polymerase II. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions can induce distinct transcriptional stalling profiles and that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings will help us to understand the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis and cancer. (Show more)

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe pneumonia in humans. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of MERS-CoV spike (S) glycoproteins. These mutations severely compromised virus infection, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. Consistent with these findings, the uncleaved S proteins were more infectious than the precleaved S proteins because they were more resistant to conformational changes that restrict the fusion-activating cleavages. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These findings may also have implications for the pathogenesis of other viruses that require sequential proteolysis for infection. (Show more)

This study provides robust evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase sales of vegetarian meals by 40% or more. This is a significant contribution to the literature on the environmental and health benefits of plant-based diets, and it has important implications for the food service industry. The study also provides evidence that nudging meal selection by increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can be effective in the real world, without the need for complex interventions or the use of incentives. This approach could be applied in a wide range of settings, including hospitals, schools, and workplaces. The study also provides evidence that nudging meal selection can be effective in the long term, without rebound effects. This study provides a clear path forward for the food service industry and policymakers to reduce the environmental and health impacts of the food system.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. We have developed a method to study the surfaceome, the collection of proteins that are attached to the cell surface. We have applied this method to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

Vote-by-mail is a popular election administration reform that has been adopted by many countries around the world. In the United States, however, vote-by-mail is still relatively uncommon, and there is little empirical evidence on its effects on electoral outcomes. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings are consistent with the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. We hope that our findings will help dispel some of the myths surrounding vote-by-mail.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has led to millions of infections and thousands of deaths. The virus has been shown to be able to evade the host immune system, and it is possible that this is due to the actions of accessory proteins such as ORF8. The structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 provides insight into how this protein may interfere with the host immune system. The structure also provides a starting point for the design of antiviral drugs. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can induce cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. This CRF is then taken up by the cortex and acts on the CRF receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a molecular understanding of the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. It also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cerebral edema. (PsycINFO Database Record

The problem of selective inference is one of the most important challenges in statistics today. It addresses the question of how to properly assess the strength of associations when we have selected a subset of the data to analyze. This is a problem that is becoming increasingly important in the era of big data, where we have access to very large datasets and sophisticated statistical methods for analyzing them. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that are required for EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can induce the generation of endothelial cells from human fibroblasts. ETV2-induced ECs (ETVECs) exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in mice. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are critical for the development of the zebrafish eye and pigment cells. Here, we show that the zebrafish genome encodes three genes that encode ligands for Alk and Ltk. We demonstrate that these ligands are essential for zebrafish pigment development and that they are required for Ltk activity. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides insights into the function of Alk and Ltk in the development of the zebrafish eye and pigment cells and may have implications for the development of human eye and pigment cell tumors. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cell remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency caused glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings also provide a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza epidemics and occasional pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in the arterial wall. The atheroprone hemodynamic environment is a key factor in the development of atherosclerotic lesions. However, the mechanisms underlying the atheroprone hemodynamic environment-induced atherogenesis are not fully understood. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by the atheroprone hemodynamic environment is a critical event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherogenesis. Our study provides a molecular mechanism for the atheroprone hemodynamic environment-induced atherogenesis and identifies YAP/TAZ as a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of atherosclerosis. These findings also provide a rationale for the development of athero-protective drugs that target YAP/TAZ. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States and elsewhere. This has led to substantial economic and ecological costs, and has increased the risk of wildfire to human communities. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the role of humans in increasing the extent of wildfire in the United States, and provides recommendations for reducing the economic and ecological costs of wildfire.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a promising strategy for pest control, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and also demonstrates the evolutionary conservation of the ancestral arthropod–plant interaction. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne virus that has recently emerged as a cause of severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The virus has been shown to replicate rapidly within infected cells, but the time between infection and production of infectious virus is unknown. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load by ∼2 d, whereas treatment given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss. Our results provide insights into the within-host dynamics of ZIKV and can be used to guide the design of antiviral treatment strategies. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most diverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth, but are currently under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. One of the most severe impacts is the breakdown of the symbiotic relationship between corals and their algae, the zooxanthellae. This process, known as coral bleaching, is triggered by a variety of environmental factors, including ocean warming. However, the underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may help us to predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing world.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the mounting of immune responses, and the prevention of systemic infections. In this study, we show that the loss of a tumor suppressor gene in Drosophila leads to the formation of intestinal tumors, which in turn, trigger a regenerative response and stimulate tumor growth. We also show that the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our study provides insights into the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings may have implications for the development of cancer therapies. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to this therapy. We show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 expression is associated with the expression of genes that are induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and that ROR1 expression is associated with the enhanced capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast

The timing of the last deglaciation is one of the most important questions in Earth science. The recent discovery of a volcanic eruption at the start of the last deglaciation has allowed us to test the hypothesis that the eruption caused the rapid climate changes. The eruption led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which is known to have a strong impact on the climate. The coincidence of the eruption and the rapid climate changes provides strong evidence that the eruption caused the rapid climate changes. This study also provides a unique opportunity to test the hypothesis that the eruption caused the rapid climate changes in a region where the climate changes are not well understood. The hypothesis is that the eruption caused a strong El Niño-like climate event, which led to the rapid climate changes. The hypothesis is supported by the results of the study.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but are often overlooked in global assessments. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and fishery sustainability. We find that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels, and that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people. Our analysis also reveals that fishing pressure is most intense in regions where rivers are most important for biodiversity conservation. This “double jeopardy” of high fishing pressure and high biodiversity importance underscores the need for improved management of inland fisheries. Our data can be used to identify areas where fisheries are most important for food security and biodiversity conservation, and can be integrated into environmental planning to protect both. This will be particularly important in the context of climate change, which is expected to increase the frequency of extreme events that can damage fisheries.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Furthermore, hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode,

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. However, the molecular mechanisms that control this regenerative capacity are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery has important implications for our understanding of the mechanisms that control the regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the regenerative capacity of the adult CNS is more robust than previously appreciated.

The process of recombination is essential for the generation of genetic diversity in sexually reproducing organisms. The distribution of recombination across genomes is a fundamental property of the genome that is important for understanding the evolution of genes and genomes. We describe the distribution of recombination across a genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and show that it exhibits many of the same features as the recombination pattern in yeast and in mice.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, in which the activity of different regions fluctuates in time. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of a set of topographies, which are reproducible across subjects and are thought to represent the main functional networks of the brain. Here, we show that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the DMN, while in PD it is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. In addition, we show that the dominant RSN is deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality is partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Finally, we show that the dominant RSN is reduced in Alzheimer’s disease, and that this abnormality is already present at diagnosis. These results provide a direct link between the functional organization of the brain and its metabolic activity. They also provide a rationale for the use of metabolic imaging in the study of the brain’s resting organization.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of eukaryotic mRNA. It is essential for translation initiation and is the target of many antiviral and anticancer drugs. The existence of 5′ modifications in bacteria has been known for decades, but the existence of 5′ modifications in eukaryotes has been unknown. We describe the existence of 5′ NAD-RNA in yeast, which is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. This 5′ modification is produced cotranscriptionally and is not found on pre-mRNAs that are 5′ end processed. These results define an additional 5′ modification in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that it could modulate mRNA stability and translation. This work also provides a new chemical modification to be considered in the design of antiviral and anticancer drugs. (Show more)

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) was a landmark study in the field of diabetes research. It showed that intensive treatment of type 1 and type 2 diabetes could prevent the development of complications. However, the long-term effects of this treatment are not fully understood. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells from people with diabetes persist for several years after the end of the DCCT, and that these differences are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for the metabolic memory phenomenon.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and is characterized by poor prognosis. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with high morbidity and mortality. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects have altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota, which is associated with the presence of psychological symptoms of the disease. These results suggest that the gut microbiota may be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The production of volatile compounds is a key feature of many plant species, and the biosynthesis of these compounds is of interest for both fundamental and applied reasons. The biosynthesis of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit is poorly understood, and the identification of the enzymes responsible for this process is a major step forward in understanding the chemistry of this important fruit.

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because both global warming and biodiversity loss are expected to occur simultaneously. Our results highlight that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning will be exacerbated if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits. This is a key finding because the majority of species are expected to be unable to tolerate the higher temperatures that are predicted to occur in the future.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-running behavior in an open field. We found that grid cells, which are essential for place learning, are anatomically segregated from other neurons, which are instead organized in a more complex way. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of neurons in MEC and suggest that grid cells are not embedded in a homogeneous population of other neurons. This organization may be important for the formation of grid cell networks. Our approach could be extended to study the organization of other cortical areas. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes and environmental cues. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for the flowering of both host and parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We demonstrate that the dopamine-containing neurons of the substantia nigra are connected to the striatum in a way that is distinct from the classical nigrostriatal pathway. Instead, the dopamine neurons are connected to the striatum by specialized integrative units that are likely critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We are often told that we should “click” with people, but how do we know when we do? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed at which we respond to others is a robust signal of how connected we feel to them. We also show that this signal is used by others to assess the quality of our connections. This signal is fast, honest, and unconscious, and thus may be a powerful way to assess connection.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate and are characterized by unique electrophysiological properties. SAN automaticity is regulated by a complex network of ion channels and stores that are activated by different types of Ca2+ signals. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SANCs and plays a key role in regulating SAN automaticity. We show that STIM1 is required for maintaining the SR Ca2+ content and the electrical activity of SANCs. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms that regulate SAN automaticity and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of arrhythmias. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Show more)

The lipidome of macrophages is a key factor in the regulation of inflammation. The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still poorly understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism in murine macrophages. We also show that the expression of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the expression of proinflammatory cytokines and for the expression of the alternative activation marker CD206. Our results demonstrate a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind linguistic features over time. This model provides a neurobiological substrate for the binding of linguistic features that is consistent with the temporal dynamics of language processing. It also provides a mechanism for the formation of short-term memory that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during learning. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants with DNA nanostructures. We show that the delivery of siRNA with DNA nanostructures depends on the DNA nanostructure geometry and the location of the siRNA attachment site on the nanostructure. We also show that the delivery of siRNA with DNA nanostructures depends on the DNA nanostructure geometry and the location of the siRNA attachment site on the nanostructure. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the delivery of biomolecules to plants in the future.

Nutrient loading from small streams is a major concern for the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. However, the relative importance of small streams has been difficult to assess because of the lack of data. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all tributaries of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. Our results reveal that small streams can be a significant source of nutrients to lakes, especially in nearshore areas where they become trapped and overlap in space. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small streams to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This approach could be applied to other large water bodies to help protect valuable coastal ecosystems from the impacts of nutrient loading.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network that is coupled to an environment that provides work to the system only in rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the system exhibits a strong tendency to concentrate in a small number of states that are extremized with respect to the environmental forcing. We discuss the implications of this behavior for the emergence of complex dynamics in complex networks of chemical reactions.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients. We use a mathematical model of cortical microcircuitry to show that NMDAR-Abs can change the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity, and that this can predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. We then use a mouse model of NMDAR-Ab encephalitis to show that the same parameter fluctuations that are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition can induce paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in the mouse model when the same parameter fluctuations are not tolerated in the mouse model of the NMDAR-Ab condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that the same parameters that are altered by NMDAR-Abs may be altered by other forms of brain dysfunction, such as seizures. This may help explain why treatment with NMDAR-Ab antibodies can lead to seizures.

The Earth system is currently undergoing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2 million years. To understand the potential impacts of such a rapid warming, it is important to understand how the Earth system responded to abrupt warming in the past. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the warming event was linked to a global-scale anoxia and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. Our results highlight the importance of understanding the Earth system response to abrupt warming in the past to better understand the potential impacts of the current rapid warming. (Show more)

The palm oil industry is the most rapidly expanding source of deforestation in the tropics, and certification is the most common tool used to meet corporate commitments to reduce this deforestation. We show that certification reduces deforestation in Indonesia, but that most certified areas still contain substantial amounts of forest. Our results suggest that certification is most effective in reducing deforestation in areas that are already degraded, and that certification is not effective in reducing deforestation in peatland areas or in reducing active fire. These findings highlight the need for certification to be coupled with other policies that reduce deforestation in intact forests.

The exocyst complex is a conserved protein complex that is essential for the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the function of many cells. The exocyst complex is conserved from bacteria to humans, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

The genetic basis of sex in vertebrates is a fundamental question in biology. In species with a single sex determination locus, the sex of an individual is determined by the genotype at that locus. In species with multiple sex determination loci, the sex of an individual is determined by the genotype at multiple loci. Here we investigate the effects of multiple sex determination loci on the secondary sexual characteristics of a species, which are the characteristics that distinguish males and females in the species. We find that multiple sex determination loci can produce a modular set of secondary sexual characteristics, which can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. This modularity of secondary sexual characteristics can also be used to understand the evolutionary consequences of the loss of sex determination in species.

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species- and light-induced photoproducts of the retinal lipofuscin pigments, which are known to contribute to age-related blindness. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of these photoproducts. We found that Fe levels, as reflected in transferrin receptor mRNA expression, were reduced in mice treated with the Fe chelator deferiprone. This reduction in Fe levels was associated with reduced levels of the lipofuscin pigments and reduced oxidative/degradation of the lipofuscin pigments in the presence of light. These findings indicate that Fe levels promote the oxidation and degradation of the lipofuscin pigments. This interpretation was supported by experiments showing that Fe chelation decreased the oxidation and degradation of the lipofuscin pigments in the presence of light. These findings have implications for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. (PsycINFO Database Record

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the diversity of their feeding strategies is a key component of their ecological and evolutionary success. However, the evolution of predator specialization is often considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of predator specialization is not only possible, but also linked to the evolution of morphological and functional innovations in separate structures dedicated to prey capture. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The fossil record for the hominin lineage leading to modern humans is relatively poor between 800,000 and 1.8 My old, a time interval well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of the distinctive stone tools of the Middle and Upper Paleolithic. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the modern human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil suggests that the distinctive human hand morphology and anatomy arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human behavior. (Show more)

The one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth, and is provided by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). Mammalian SHMT1 is cytosolic, and SHMT2 is mitochondrial. We show that dual knockout of SHMT1/2 blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also identify a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT1/2, which is effective in cellular models. However, one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition, and paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a cancer cell-line screen. We show that formate is a more effective inhibitor of SHMT2 than SHMT1, and that formate inhibition of SHMT2 is defective in a cancer cell line that is uniquely dependent upon SHMT2 for glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer cells. This work provides a rationale for the use of formate as a cancer therapeutic. (Show more)

This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated when forests are fragmented. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Modern agriculture is a major contributor to global food production, but it is also a major cause of soil degradation. The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural production, but it has also increased the weight of vehicles, which has led to compaction of soil layers that are normally resistant to mechanical stress. We show that the weight of modern farm machinery has exceeded the mechanical limits of soil compaction resistance, and that this trend has been increasing over time. We also show that the weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, suggesting that the effects of subsoil compaction on land productivity were similar to those of these prehistoric giants.
